message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ocular findings suggest a lesion of the sixth cranial nerve, which affects lateral eye movement. An associated physical exam finding is horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze, which indicates internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Ptosis on the right suggests a lesion of the third cranial nerve, left abduction palsy suggests a lesion of the third cranial nerve on the left, and afferent pupillary defect suggests optic neuropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s right adduction palsy on leftward gaze suggests a lesion affecting the right lateral rectus muscle. Among the options, only horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with the lesion responsible for her ocular findings, which is an internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) affecting the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) in the brainstem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms indicate a lesion in the left medial rectus muscle or its innervating nerve. A horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with a lesion in the abducens nerve, which is responsible for lateral rectus muscle movement. Ptosis on the right is associated with a lesion in the oculomotor nerve, but this would affect other ocular movements as well. Left abduction palsy on leftward gaze would be consistent with a lesion in the left lateral rectus muscle or its innervating nerve. An afferent pupillary defect in the left eye would suggest optic nerve involvement, but this is not associated with the patient's ocular findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s double vision is caused by the right adduction palsy on leftward gaze. Among the options, only horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with the lesion responsible for her ocular findings, specifically the left abducens nerve palsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The right adduction palsy on leftward gaze suggests a lesion affecting the right abducens (VI) cranial nerve. Among the options, only horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with a lesion in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). Together this makes up the classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). Ptosis is suggestive of a third nerve palsy, left abduction palsy on leftward gaze would be seen with a left abducens (VI) cranial nerve palsy, and an afferent pupillary defect suggests an optic nerve lesion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has right adduction palsy on leftward gaze, which suggests a lesion affecting the sixth cranial nerve. Among the options, horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with a lesion affecting the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which is frequently involved in sixth nerve palsies. Ptosis on the right suggests a lesion affecting the oculomotor nerve, left abduction palsy on leftward gaze suggests a lesion affecting the left abducens nerve, and an afferent pupillary defect in the left eye suggests a lesion affecting the optic nerve or retina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ocular findings and the previous episode of right arm weakness suggest a possible neurological condition. Among the options, only horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with the lesion responsible for her ocular findings, which is believed to be the sixth cranial nerve palsy or abducens nerve palsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with right adduction palsy on leftward gaze, which is likely caused by a lesion in the sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve) on the right side. Horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus, which connects cranial nerves III, IV, and VI, and is responsible for coordinating eye movements. Ptosis on the right would suggest a lesion in the oculomotor nerve on the same side. Left abduction palsy on leftward gaze would suggest a lesion in the abducens nerve on the left side. An afferent pupillary defect in the left eye would suggest optic nerve or retinal pathology but is not specific to the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s right adduction palsy on leftward gaze suggests a lesion in the abducens nerve. Among the options, only horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with an abducens nerve lesion. Ptosis indicates oculomotor nerve involvement, left abduction palsy indicates sixth nerve involvement, and afferent pupillary defect suggests optic nerve involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The right adduction palsy on leftward gaze suggests a sixth nerve palsy, and horizontal nystagmus in the left eye on leftward gaze is associated with a lesion responsible for the ocular findings. Ptosis on the right, left abduction palsy on leftward gaze, and afferent pupillary defect in the left eye are not associated with this particular lesion.
